hProperties.aria-label: gatsby plugin purgecss npm version permalink
what is this plugin about permalink

children.value: Remove unused css from css/sass/less/stylus files and modules in your Gatsby project using
😯 to make sure gatsby-plugin-purgecss does not cause you issues and
npm i gatsby-plugin-purgecss
Add the plugin AFTER other css/postcss plugins

// gatsy-config.js
module.exports = {
  plugins: [
    `gatsby-plugin-stylus`,
    `gatsby-plugin-sass`,
    `gatsby-plugin-less`,
    `gatsby-plugin-postcss`,
    // Add after these plugins if used
    { 
      resolve: `gatsby-plugin-purgecss`,
      options: {
        printRejected: true, // Print removed selectors and processed file names
        // develop: true, // Enable while using `gatsby develop`
        // tailwind: true, // Enable tailwindcss support
        // whitelist: ['whitelist'], // Don't remove this selector
        // ignore: ['/ignored.css', 'prismjs/', 'docsearch.js/'], // Ignore files/folders
        // purgeOnly : ['components/', '/main.css', 'bootstrap/'], // Purge only these files/folders
      }
    }
  ]
};
Read about all the available options.
option to print the removed selectors.
Only files processed by Webpack will be purged.
Whitelist required selectors or ignore files/folder using the
To only purge specific files/packages use

children.value: Issue 2: Selectors with dashes in name gets removed when used with named imports

hProperties.aria-label: issue 5 using npm packages with components which import css files permalink

children.value: Issue 5: Using npm packages with components which import css files

If you import a npm package which imports its own styles locally, then gatsby-plugin-purgecss will incorrectly remove all the css imported by the package. It’s because by default the selectors are only matched with the files under ‘src’ folder.
To get around this, you could:
Ignore the file completely using the
Whitelist the required selectors as described in the next section.

and add the package’s path.
Eg:

content: [
path.join(process.cwd(), 'src/**/!(*.d).{ts,js,jsx,tsx}'),
path.join(process.cwd(), 'node_modules/my-npm-package/folder-to-match/!(*.d).{ts,js,jsx,tsx}')
];
You can use any of these techniques to stop purgecss from removing required styles

hProperties.aria-label: 1 whitelist the selector using the whitelist option in gatsby configjs permalink

children.value: 1. Whitelist the selector using the whitelist option in gatsby-config.js
whitelist: ['my-selector']

hProperties.aria-label: 2 for selector with dashes in them and using named imports permalink

children.value: 2. For selector with dashes in them and using named imports

// my-selector
<div className={style.mySelector} />
This comment can be in any script file inside

hProperties.aria-label: 4  use regex pattern to exclude many selectors permalink

children.value: 4.  Use Regex pattern to exclude many selectors
whitelistPatterns: [/^btn/]
For eg, this pattern will whitelist all selectors starting with btn: btn btn-primary btn-secondary etc.
in purgecss to also whitelist children of the selectors.

hProperties.aria-label: 5 use purgecss ignore comment in css file permalink

children.value: 5. Use purgecss ignore comment in css file

/* purgecss ignore */
.my-selector { color: 'white' }
This comment will ignore the selector on the next line.

hProperties.aria-label: 6 use purgecss ignore block comments in css file permalink

children.value: 6. Use purgecss ignore block comments in css file

/* purgecss start ignore */
button { color: 'white' };
.yo { color: 'blue' };
/* purgecss end ignore */
This comment pair will ignore all css selectors between them.

hProperties.aria-label: 7 ignore files and folder using the ignore options permalink

children.value: 7. Ignore files and folder using the ignore options
ignore: ['ignoredFile.css', 'ignoredFolder/', 'sub/folder/ignore/', 'inFolder/file.css']

Purgecss relies on extractors to get the list of selector used in a file. The default extractor considers every word of a file as a selector.
You could use your own extractor (or get one made by other community members) to improve detection and further decrease your css file size.
If you do find/write a better extractor suited for Gatsby, please help me add it to the docs.
By default, this plugin only runs when building the project (

It will print the amount of css removed.
To run it while using
The size reported by this plugin is the approximate size of the css content
The actual file size should be smaller.
This plugin loads css files (or transformed output from css plugins) and searches for matching selectors in js, jsx, ts, tsx files in
. It does not know which css file belongs to which source file. Therefore, for eg., if there is a class
in some css file, it will not be removed if it used in
Since html and body tags do not appear in
files, it is whitelisted by default to not be removed.
Since v2.3.0, manually including ‘html’, ‘body’ is no longer required.

hProperties.aria-label: using with postcss syntax plugins permalink

children.value:
should work with other postcss plugins.
For older versions:

is executed before postcss loader and can only purge css syntax. If you are using any syntax based postcss plugin, then it may not get purged. In such cases you will see “Could not parse file, skipping. Your build will not break.” message.

will simply ignore the file and continue without issue.
It would be better if you use purgecss postcss plugin directly instead.
This plugins supports most purgecss options as is (except
Read about purgecss options in detail
Options can be specified in your

module.exports = {
  plugins: [
    {
      resolve: 'gatsby-plugin-purgecss',
      options: {
        printRejected: true,
      }
    }
  ]
};
Print the amount of css removed
rejected: true
Print the list of removed selectors
printRejected: true
It will print maximum of 100 removed selector per file to keep the output readable.
To view all the removed selector enable the
to print all the rejected selectors.
printAll: true
whitelist: ['my-selector', 'footer']
Since v2.3.0 manually including ‘html’, ‘body’ is no longer required.
purgeOnly: ['/main.css', 'bootstrap/', 'node_modules/font-awesome/']
Stop these files or folders from getting purged.
ignore: ['/ignoredFile.css', 'ignoredFolder/', 'sub/folder/ignore/', 'inFolder/file.css']
tailwind: true
Uses extractors needed for parsing tailwind class names.
Enable if you are using tailwindcss.
develop: true
This does not print the total css removed.
To see what is being removed, use it with the
debug: true
It will write two files to disk.

content: [
  path.join(process.cwd(), 'src/**/!(*.d).{ts,js,jsx,tsx}'),
  path.join(process.cwd(), 'anotherFolder/!(*.d).{ts,js,jsx,tsx}')
];
whitelistPatterns: [/button/, /^fa-/, /main$/]
This example will whitelist selectors containing “button”, starting with “fa-” and ending with “main”.
, it will also whitelist children of the selectors.
whitelistPatternsChildren: [/red$/]
In the example, selectors such as
will be left in the final CSS.
